metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Influence of wind and relative humidity on the social distancing effectiveness to prevent COVID-19 airborne transmission: A numerical study Influence of Wind and Relative Humidity on the Social Distancing Effectiveness to Prevent COVID-19 Airborne Transmission: A Numerical Study 4 5 Phone: (405)744-7441

affiliation.institution: ANSYS Belgium S.A., Center d'Affaires "Les Collines de Wavre"

abstract.text: It has been confirmed that the coronavirus disease 2019 can transmit through 2 droplets created when an infected human coughs or sneezes. Accordingly, 1.83-m (6-feet) social 3 distancing is advised to reduce the spread of the disease among humans. This is based on the 4 assumption that no air circulation exists around people. However, it is not well investigated 5 whether the ambient wind and relative humidity (RH) will cause SARS-CoV-2 laden droplets to 6 transport farther in the air, making the current social distancing policy insufficient. To provide 7 evidence and insight into the "social distancing" guidelines, a validated computational fluid-8 particle dynamics (CFPD) model was employed to simulate the transient transport, 9 condensation/evaporation, and deposition of SARS-CoV-2 laden droplets emitted by coughs, 10 with different environmental wind velocities and RHs. Initial droplet diameters range from 2 to 11 2000 µm, and the wind velocities range from 0 to 16 km/h, representing different wind forces 12 from calm air to moderate breeze. The comparison between a steady-state wind and a gust with a 13 constant frequency has also been performed. Ambient RHs are 40% and 99.5%. The distances 14 between the two virtual humans are 1.83 m and 3.05 m (6 feet and 10 feet). The facial covering 15

effect on reducing the airborne transmission of the cough droplets has also been evaluated. 16 Numerical results indicate that the ambient wind will enhance the complexity of the secondary 17 flows with recirculation between the two virtual humans. Microdroplets follow the airflow 18 streamlines well and deposit on both human bodies and head regions, even with the 3.05-m (10-19 feet) separation distance. The rest of the microdroplets can transport in the air farther than 3.05 m 20 (10 feet) due to wind convection, causing a potential health risk to nearby people. High RH will 21 increase the droplet sizes due to the hygroscopic growth effect, which increases the deposition 22 fractions on both humans and the ground. With the complex environmental wind and RH 23 conditions, the 6-feet social distancing policy may not be sufficient to protect the inter-person 24 aerosol transmission, since the suspending micro-droplets were influenced by convection effects 25 and can be transported from the human coughs/sneezes to the other human in less than 5 seconds.

Thus, due to the complex real-world environmental ventilation conditions, a social distance 27 longer than 6 feet needs to be considered. Wearing masks should also be recommended for both 28 infected and healthy humans to reduce the airborne cough droplet numbers. 29

body_text.text: As the world faces a large outbreak of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) epidemic, the 2 airborne transmission risk of the novel severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS- 3 CoV-2) was first confirmed by the National Health Commission of the People's Republic of 4 China (J. Wang & Du, 2020) , and then by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). 5 Although the virus diameter of SARS-CoV-2 is from 50 to 200 nm (Guzman, 2020) , it has been 6 confirmed that SARS-CoV-2 spreads through inhalation or ingestions of droplets they 7 contaminate. As a result, coughing, sneezing, and touching infected surfaces are primary sources 8 of infection. As a cellular entry receptor for SARS-CoV-2 (H. Zhang, Penninger, Li, Zhong, & 9 Slutsky, 2020), Angiotensin Converting Enzyme 2 (ACE-2) are abundantly present in humans in 10 the epithelia of the lung and small intestine, as well as present in mucosae (mouth and nose) or 11 conjunctiva (eyes). Therefore, it is critical to prevent the SARS-CoV-2 laden droplets from 12 reaching the respiratory systems or the eyes. To slow the spread of COVID-19 via airborne 13 transmission, a "social distancing" policy of approximately 1.83 m (6 feet) is recommended. 14 However, this social distance is defined with static ambient air which is not realistic, and also 15 neglects the effect of relative humidity (Drossinos & Stilianakis, 2020) . In addition, it is often 16 assumed that most of the respiratory droplets fall and reach the floor. However, emitted micro- 17 droplets have low Stokes numbers (Finlay, 2001) , which can be significantly influenced by the 18 convection of ambient airflow and transport much farther than 1.83 m. Such an unknown effect 19 increases the complexity of social distancing policy making and may pose potential risks to 20 people in contact with the airborne SARS-CoV-2. Therefore, it is necessary to systematically 21 investigate how the ambient wind and relative humidity can influence the air transmission of 22 SARS-CoV-2-laden droplets generated by coughs from a COVID-19 positive patient to a healthy 23 human subject standing farther than 1.83 (6 feet) away. Such research is also crucial because 24 visualizing the airborne transmission of the SARS-CoV-2-laden droplets between humans to 25 inform people to be aware of the importance to personal protection equipment (PPE), and to be 26 responsible for helping reduce the spread of the virus to protect susceptible population groups, 27 i.e., seniors with underlying conditions such as influenza, cystic fibrosis, and diabetes. 28 Supported by benchmark experimental data from cough aerosol characterizations (Bourouiba, 33 done to either characterize cough aerosol clouds or simulate aerosol transport phenomena in both 34 indoor and outdoor environments. However, most of the numerical studies, either using Euler- 35 Euler or Euler-Lagrange based models, neglected the condensation and evaporation of the cough 36 droplets, which may limit the validity of droplet trajectory predictions. Based on our literature employed a single virtual human, and did not investigate potential exposure health risks to the 5 cough droplets for a second virtual human nearby. 6 This study employed a well-validated computational fluid-particle dynamics (CFPD) model (X. size changes due to condensation and evaporation to simulate SARS-CoV-2-laden droplets 11 transmission between two virtual humans, quantify the wind and relative humidity effects on the 12 droplet deposition on the human body and head region, and provide guidance on fine-tuning the 13 social distancing policy based on environmental parameters. Specifically, using benchmark data 14 of cough aerosol characterizations (Duguid, 1946 This study provides aerosol transmission dynamics simulations on understanding the basic 25 aerosol science of SARS-CoV-2-laden droplets spread through the air. The research is significant 26 since it will benefit the research community and regulatory agencies, with the potential to 27 enhance the fundamental understanding of how environmental and human factors can influence 28 the airborne viral transmission from person to person. The insight and quantitative exposure data 29 of the head region and the human body will provide direct evidence for prevention guidance to 30 reduce exposure and infection risks. This study can also be extended to provide high-resolution 31 virus-laden droplet transport and deposition predictions in human respiratory systems with 32 different social distancing paradigms, and to estimate the SARS-CoV-2 RNA load in the airways 33 for further understanding of the viral infection, replication, and pathogenesis noninvasively in the

A confined environment, i.e., a rectangular space with two virtual humans separated at different 39 distances, i.e., 1.83 m and 3.05 m (6 feet and 10 feet), are reconstructed (see Fig. 1 ). The two 40 virtual humans are identical to the model used in previous studies . The mouth 41 opening is created for the virtual human on the left with a hydraulic diameter equal to 10 mm, 1 and the center coordinate of the opening is (0, 0, 0.034) m. 2 Unstructured hybrid polyhedron plus prism meshes were generated using ANSYS Fluent 3 Meshing 19.2 (ANSYS Inc., Canonsburg, PA). Specifically, six prism layers were created near 4 the wall surface to contain the viscous sub-layers to calculate near-wall gradients accurately. 5 Mesh details are shown in Fig. 1 . The thickness of the first prism layer guarantees y + <1 to 6 capture the laminar-to-turbulence transition sites using the Transition Shear Stress Transport 7 (SST) Model (Menter, Kuntz, & Langtry, 2003) . Specifically, y + is the dimensionless wall 8 distance, or local near-wall Reynolds number (Yu Feng et al., 2018) . The mesh topology was 9 determined by refining the mesh until grid independence of the flow field solutions was achieved.

As an example, the final mesh of the computational domain with the 6-feet separation distance 11 between the two virtual humans contains 2,638,753 elements and 9,572,670 nodes. 12 13 To model the transport, size change, and deposition of the emitted virus-laden droplets generated 18 With the Eulerian descriptions, the ambient airflow field can be predicted by solving the 19 conservation laws. Thus, the well-validated shear stress transport (SST) transition model (Menter et al., 2003) 27 was adopted in this study, based on its overall good performance, predicting "laminar-to- 28 turbulent" transition onset, computational efficiency and reasonable accuracy when compared to 29 large eddy simulation (LES).

body_text.text: A cough can turn human mouths into atomizers (Settles, 2006) . In this study, the widest span of 11 the cough droplet size distribution measurements was used (Duguid, 1946 ) (see Fig. 2 (b)). 12 Specifically, those droplets consist of saliva and mucus and range in diameters from 2 to 2000

Deposition occurs once the droplet contacts the body shells of the virtual humans and ground. 22 Droplet size and spatial location were recorded when the droplet deposited on the boundary or 23 escaped from the computational domain. 24 25 The ambient wind velocities range from 0 to 16 km/h, representing Beaufort wind scales from 26 calm air to moderate breeze (Beer, 2013) . The potentially most risky wind direction, from the 27 infected virtual human (left in Fig.1 ) to the other virtual human (right in Fig. 1) , has been 28 employed. The wind inlet temperature is assumed to be 27 ºC. Two RHs are used in this study, 29 i.e., (1) RH=40%, which is the lower bound of the ideal humidity for health and comfort, and (2) 30 RH=99.5%, which is the highly humid environment close to saturation. 32 It is assumed that the wind velocity and direction is steady-state. Accordingly, the steady-state 33 airflow fields generated by different wind conditions were employed to initialize the numerical 34 simulations before introducing the transient cough-jet waveform and the emitted virus-laden 35 droplets. An example can be found in Fig. 1 at the midplane Y=0. ). Specifically, regional deposition efficiencies (RDEs) predicted by the CFPD 35 model employed in this study were compared with benchmark experimental data in 36 physical models of lung airways, with the inhalation flow rate from 15 to 60 L/min.

Comparisons show good agreements between the numerical and experimental studies. healthy virtual human to the right. In addition, the recirculation zone downstream to the healthy 18 virtual human (right in Fig. 1 ) lead to droplet deposition on the backside. when the ambient wind velocity is zero (see Fig. 2 (a) ). It can be observed that large droplets 5 move faster and stay more concentrated than small droplets. This is because large droplets have 6 relatively high Stokes number, indicating the less dominant effect of viscous dissipation forces 7 acting on them. Therefore, they are more "capable" of keeping their initial trajectories. In 8 contrast, with the larger surface area to volume ratio, small droplets lose their initial momentum 9 and kinetic energy quickly due to the viscous dissipation effect from the drag force mainly. Thus, Accordingly, Figures 8 and 9 show the local deposition patterns and regional deposition Therefore, it is necessary to avoid body contact with others before changing clothes and washing 8 hands after possible exposure. 9 Because of the discrepancies of RH and wind influences on the depositions between large and 10 small droplets, regional deposition fractions (DFs) are calculated and shown in Figs. 9 (a)-(d) . It . 10 (a) and (c) ). 18 Therefore, the wind effect on the droplet deposition is obscure and needs further investigation 19 with different wind velocities and directions. mentioning that the wind effect is negligible on the droplet size changes of suspending droplets, 33 since the wind volumetric flow rate is much larger than the cough jet, so that the relative 34 humidity in the computational domain is determined by the RH carried by the wind velocity. Since Figures 8 and 9 have demonstrated that L sd =1.83 m (6 feet) cannot sufficiently protect the 2 healthy virtual human from exposure of the cough droplets with ambient winds, it is beneficial to 3 investigate whether a longer L sd will be a better standard to be used for the social distancing 4 policy. Therefore, two additional simulations with L sd =3.05 m (10 feet) and RH=99.5% were 5 done with two different wind conditions, i.e., steady-state moderate breeze V in =5.5 m/s, and a 6 transient gust with a waveform of V in shown in Fig. 11 (a) . Droplet deposition patterns and 7 transport of the two 10-feet cases are visualized in Fig. 11 (b)-(f), and compared with the 6-feet 8 case with the same RH and wind velocity (see Figs. 7 (a)-(d) and Fig. 8 (c) ). 9 With the steady-state V in =5.5 m/s, the comparison between Fig. 8 (c) and Fig. 11 (b) shows that

Another evidence can be found by the deposition pattern differences shown in between 16 Fig. 8 (c) and Fig. 11 (b) . No large droplets deposit on the human who coughs in Fig. 11 (b) than 17 Fig. 8 (c) , indicating that no large droplets moved backward in the 3.05 m cases. The other 18 groups of large droplets in red are dominated by the gravitational sedimentation and deposit on 19 the ground due to the larger L sd =3.05 m (see Fig. 8 (c) and Fig. 11 (b) ). In contrast, 20 microdroplets in blue will still be able to follow the mainstream and transport to the head region 30 it is interesting to find that the gust condition was able to convect the cough droplets faster 31 towards the healthy human direction than the steady-state wind condition. The gust also leads to 32 higher deposition on the healthy human and no deposition on the human who coughs (see Fig. 11 33 (b)). The difference in droplet transport and deposition between the steady-state wind and the 34 gust is due to the difference in the recirculating flow patterns between the two virtual humans. 35 Specifically, the interval gust condition will not generate the quasi-steady-state recirculations, 36 which lead to the faster transport of the droplets towards the downstream direction. Without 37 moving upstream, no droplets deposited on the human who coughs, and more droplets 38 transported downstream and deposited on the healthy human. Thus, with the same peak wind 39 velocities, the gust enhances the exposure risk of the healthy human compared to the steady-state 40 wind condition. To further investigate the effect of facial covering, a virtual N95 filtering facepiece respirator 2 (FFR) was reconstructed and positioned close to the virtual human who coughs (see Fig. 12 (a) ). 3 The average gap between the face contour and the edge of the N95 mask was intentionally 4 exaggerated to approximately 1.8 cm, mimicking the worst scenario with the inappropriate mask 5 seal. Employing the realistic filtration efficiencies as a function of particle diameter (see Fig. 12 6 (b)), a customized C code was programmed to reflect the probabilities of particle trapping 7 accurately when the cough droplets enter the N95 mask which is assumed to be a porous media 8 region. For example, when entering the N95 mask region, the C code will generate a random 9 number between 0 and 1 for each particle. If the random number is lower than the filtration 10 efficiency for the specific particle diameter, then the particle will be assigned a velocity equal to 11 zero, which indicates it has been captured by the mask. For the computational domain of the N95 12 mask, the porosity is 0.88, and the viscous resistance coefficient is 1.12e10 m -2 , which is based cannot be captured by the mask, the total number of the cough droplets transport in the air is 19 significantly lower than the case without the mask (see Fig. 7) . With the mask, airborne droplets 20 are all relatively small, and entering the airflow is slightly delayed. However, those small 21 droplets can still follow the mainstream airflow streamlines (see Fig. 1 (c) ) and reach the healthy 22 virtual human on the right. Thus, it can be concluded that even if wearing facial masks without 23 the proper seal with the face can significantly reduce the airborne transmission of cough droplets. 24 It is recommended that people can wear facial coverings with minimized gaps with their faces.

The minimum infectious dose of SARS-CoV-2 is unknown so far, but researchers suspect that it 33 is low. More viruses may lead to more severe COVID-19 symptoms. Therefore, it is certain that 34 lowering the exposure risks to SARS-CoV-2 around healthy people will reduce the infection further. Wearing PPEs, avoiding handshakes, and washing hands frequently are necessary. 8 During the current period without COVID-19 vaccines, the current social distancing policy needs 9 to be refined with larger separation distances to slow down the spread of the virus.However, it 10 does not necessarily mean that a more strict social distancing policy will be 100% beneficial for

To slow the spread of the COVID-19 virus via airborne transmission, although a "social 17 distancing" policy of approximately 1.83 m (6 feet) is recommended, it needs to be scrutinized. 18 By visualizing the trajectories and fates of SARS-CoV-2-laden droplets with various ambient 19 conditions using the CFPD model with modeling the condensation/evaporation effects between 20 the ambient water vapor and the droplets, this study found that the 1.83 m (6 feet) social 21 distancing policy is the "minimum requirement" and is not sufficient to avoid the contact of (1) A carrier of COVID-19 who coughs can produce virus-laden droplets in micron size that 28 remain viable in the air exposing healthy people near (6ft) and far(10ft) from the source 29 in a static air environment.

(2) Wind effect on the droplet transport and deposition is complex and highly dependent on 31 the wake flow patterns and localized secondary flow intensities between the two virtual 32 humans, as well as the steadiness of the wind. It is certain that the current 6-feet social 33 policy is not sufficient to protect people from SARS-CoV-2 exposure generated by 34 coughs with the ambient wind.

(3) High RH=99.5% leads to higher deposition fractions on both human bodies and the 36 ground, which is not necessarily related to higher exposure risks. High RH=99.5% can 37 enhance the condensation effect, and the cough droplet sizes keep growing during their 38 transport in the air until the partial pressure at the droplet surface is equal to the saturation 39 pressure of water vapor. In contrast, RH=40% triggers the evaporation of the water in 40 cough droplets, thereby leading to droplet size reduction, which may lead to a longer time 1 suspended in the air. The present numerical study is subjected to the following simplifications and assumptions: 9 (1) The virtual humans are assumed to be static without any motion;

(2) The atomization and coagulation between cough liquid ligand and droplets were not 11 modeled, and the experimental data of the droplet size distribution is assumed to be the The future work will be done continuously to enhance the fundamental understanding of the 35 airborne transmission of SARS-CoV-2 for better preparations against the post-pandemic period 36 with the high possibility of resurgence (Kissler et al., 2020) .
• Air Transmission of cough droplets with condensation and evaporation effects are modeled between two virtual humans.
• Relative humidity (RH) has a noticeable influence on droplet size change dynamics.
• High RH (99.5%) lead to higher deposition fractions of cough droplets on both virtual humans than low RH (40%).
• Six-feet social distancing policy for COVID-19 is not sufficient with ambient wind conditions

FIGREF26.text: 2019 R1 (ANSYS Inc., Canonsburg, PA) was used to simulate the transient 38 airborne transmission of the cough droplets carried by the ambient airflows, with condensation 39 and evaporation. The flow time step is t f =1.0e-3 s, and the maximum droplet time step is 1 t d =1.0e-5 s, which are all based on in-house time-step independence test. All simulations stopped 2 at 15 s, or stopped earlier when the suspending droplets in the domain are less than 1% of the 3 total number of droplets injected. Numerical simulations were performed on a local Dell 4 Precision T7910 workstation (Intel®Xeon® Processor E5-2683 v4 with dual processors, 64 5 cores, and 256 GB RAM). Using 32 cores, it took approximately 8 hours to complete one 6 simulation with an 8-second flow time duration. FIGREF28.text: Airflow Field vs. Wind Velocity V in 1 Figures 3 (a)-(c) visualizes airflow fields and localized recirculations of the wake flow using the 2 nondimensionalized air velocity contours V*=V/V in at planes X=0 and Y=0 with streamlines. 3 The distributions of V* have no significant changes with the increase in wind velocity V in . 4 However, with the increase in V in , the strength and complexity of the recirculating flows are 5 enhanced, which can be observed form the topology changes of the streamlines at Y=0. The 6 intensified recirculating flows have impacts on the cough droplet transport with higher V in (see 7 Section 3.3). Furthermore, high-velocity flows exist outside of the wake flow formed 8 downstream to the human who coughs (left inFig. 1), which can be both observed from the 9 velocity contours at planes X=0 and Y=0. Specifically, as the V* contours shown at plane X=0 10 inFigs. 3 (a)-(c), the higher velocity outside of the wake flow generates secondary flows and11    vortices rotating towards the centerline between the two virtual humans. These horizontal 12 secondary flow patterns also restrict the dispersion of the cough droplets in Y direction during13 their transport, and most of the droplets were not able to escape from the wake flow region (see14 Section 3.3).The airflow streamlines also show that the wind flow near the ground is able to15    pass between the legs of the left virtual human and rise towards the head region of the right16 virtual human, which indicates the possibility to lift settling droplets toward the face of the17

FIGREF30.text: To manifest the wind and RH effect on the airborne droplet transmission, Figures 4 to 7 show 21 the droplet trajectories and their size changes at different time stations with different V in and RH. 22 Selecting t=0.5 s as the representative time when the cough jet ends, the droplet sizes and 23 positions in different cases are visualized in Fig. 4 (a)-(h). With V in increases from 0 to 5.5 m/s, 24 the convection due to the ambient wind becomes more dominant to small droplets. This can be 25 proved by the smaller distance between the frontier of the droplet cloud and the healthy human to 26 the right in the figures with V in increases. It is interesting to see that larger droplets are not 27 affected by the enhanced wind velocity when V in <5.5 m/s. Specifically, the large droplets in 28 gray color, all traveled approximately 1.81 m at t=0.5 s in Figs. 4 (a)-(f). Such an observation 29 indicates that those the inertia and gravitational sedimentation are dominant for those large 30 droplets. The exceptions are shown in Figs. 4 (g) and (h). The enhanced localized turbulence 31 intensity and airflow momentum in the recirculation zones between the two virtual humans, 32 larger droplets are influenced and moved back towards the left human who coughs. Indeed, With 33 high wind velocity entering the computational domain, the local airflow velocities in the 34 recirculation zone have higher magnitude and higher turbulence intensity. Therefore, the 35 convection effect is more dominant so that it can influence the larger droplets and conquer their 36 inertia, forcing them to follow the backward recirculation flow. Such trajectories led to the 37 deposition patterns of the droplets in gray color shown in Figs. 8 (c) and (d). Moreover, the RH 38 effect on the droplet size change dynamics is noticeable. Droplet sizes in cases with RH=99.5% 39 (see Figs. 4 (a), (c), (e) and (g)) are larger than the cases with RH=40% (see Figs. (b), (d), (f), 40 and (h)) This is because the high RH (99.5%) enhances the hygroscopic growths of the droplets, 41 while the low RH (40%) leads to droplet shrinkage due to the evaporation.42 Comparisons of the droplet transport shown in Figs. 5 to 7 from two different angles can provide 1 the insight of wind and RH influence on SARS-CoV-2 laden droplet airborne transmission. (a)-(f) visualize the cough droplets positions and sizes at different times in static air 3 from t=1.0 s to t=15.0 s. Droplets can only obtain momentum and energy from the cough jet 4

FIGREF31.text: they are dispersed very fast in static air.Figures 15 (e)and (f) demonstrate that with the current11    1.83 m (6-feet) social distancing policy, microdroplets can still transport to the head region of the 12 healthy virtual human standing on the right. Therefore, the current social distancing policy is not13 100% safe even for the ideal static air condition.14 The comparisons between Figs. 5 and 6 visualize the wind effect on the droplet transport. With 15 V in =5.5 m/s, the wind convection is dominant on small droplet trajectories. Specifically, the 16 droplets are restricted in the region with a width approximately equal to the with of the shoulders.17This is because the horizontal recirculation flows towards the centerline between the two humans 18 (seeFigs. 3 (a)-(c)). In addition, the dominant wind convection conveys extra momentum and19    kinetic energy to the droplets and accelerates them to move faster towards the head region of the 20 healthy human to the right following the airflow streamlines (see Figs. 6 (c) and 5 (c)). With the 21 recirculation effect in the vertical direction compared with the static air, some droplets traveled22    backward and stayed around the left human who coughs. Therefore, the ambient wind will make23 the small droplets transport dynamics become more complex, and can potentially provide higher24 kinetic energy to them and make them travel farther in the air.

Such 41 phenomena are possibly due to the different droplet size change dynamics, which altered the 42 transient droplet-air interactions and the resultant droplet trajectories and their deposition sites. to more depositions of larger droplets on both humans. FIGREF36.text: d) visualized the fraction of droplets 20 suspending in the computational domain at t=15 s. For static air condition (V in =0), there are more 21 droplets suspending in the air with RH=40% than RH=99.5%. Such an observation indicates that 22 high RH may lead to faster gravitational sedimentation of airborne droplets due to the 23 hygroscopic growth effect. For the cases with ambient winds, the fractions of suspending 24 droplets are not significantly influenced by the RH. FIGREF43.text: Recommendations on Viral Load Estimations26    Viral load is not considered in this numerical study, based on the fact that viral loading in a 27 cough droplet is still unknown. However, for the future work, it can be assumed that the viral28 RNA load copies/ml in the cough droplet is identical to the specimen collected from COVID-1929 patients exhibiting coughing symptoms (J. Y.Kim et al., 2019), or the saliva data from infected30    ferrets, which is 10 1.73±0.54 copies per mL (Y.-I.Kim et al., 2020).

FIGREF45.text: risks. Indeed, it is not 100% likelihood of infection if there are SARS-CoV-2 virus deposits on36 the human body or head regions. However, increasing social distance L sd and avoiding standing 37 at the downwind position when talking to other people will effectively reduce the exposure risks.

FIGREF46.text: If the wind direction is constant, it is ideal that the two humans should make sure that "the 39 discussion should be orthogonal to the wind," meaning the wind should be in a direction40 perpendicular to the centerlines connecting the two humans. However, wind velocity and 41 direction varies from time to time in reality. 1 Furthermore, recent studies (N Van Doremalen et al.; Neeltje van Doremalen et al., 2020) 2 demonstrate that aerosols containing SARS-CoV-2 remained infectious in air, on surfaces, and in 3 tissue-culture assays with only a slight reduction in infectivity for hours of observation. Based on 4 the observation from this study, microdroplets in this study can either suspend and transport in 5 the air farther than 1.83 m (6 feet) or deposit on human bodies. Thus, only keeping the social 6 distancing guidelines as of May 2020 is not sufficient, and the guidelines should be scrutinized 7

FIGREF47.text: the long term. More effective social distancing policies have the possibility to slow down the 12 development of herd immunity to COVID-19 and may enhance the chance for the resurgence 13(Kissler et al., 2020). Therefore, more factors beyond the aerosol dynamics need to be integrated14 for decision making.

FIGREF49.text: CoV-2 due to the complexity of environmental wind conditions. These conclusions do not 23 consider the sneeze droplet cloud that can span approximately up to 8 m (27 feet) (Bourouiba, 24 2020). Therefore, a safe social distance is highly dependent on different factors, so it is highly 25 recommended that people wear masks and other face coverings when in public. Major 26 conclusions are listed as follows:27

FIGREF50.text: Although longer social distance can reduce the cough droplet depositions on the human 3 body, there are still SARS-CoV-2 laden droplets that may suspend near the head region 4 or deposit on the healthy human. Even wearing facial masks in an unrealistically loose condition when coughing can 6 significantly reduce the suspension of small droplets in the air.7 5. Limitations of the Study and Future Work8

FIGREF51.text: The study does not consider the effect of other critical factors on the airborne14 transmission of the SARS-CoV-2-laden droplets; and15    (4) The resultant inhalation, transport, and deposition of SARS-CoV-2-laden droplets, and 16 the triggered immune system responses were not modeled and studied. Indeed,17 Inspired by the limitations of this study, future work will:18 (1) Use large eddy simulation (LES) instead of RANS model combined with overset mesh 19 method to model the turbulence ambient airflow fields waked by the walking motion of 20 human (Edge, Paterson, & Settles, 2005; Settles, 2006); Consider the atomization and coagulation between liquid bulk and droplets using the 22 hybrid volume of fluid (VOF)-discrete phase model (DPM) method (Balasubramanian, 23 Kumar, Nakod, Schütze, & Rajan, 2020; Xiao, Liu, & Liu, 2019); 24 (3) Perform extensive parametric analysis to seek for other vital factors that can influence the 25 airborne transmission of the SARS-CoV-2 laden droplets, e.g., droplet size distributions 26 generated by different emission activities (e.g., sneeze (Hassani & Khorramymehr, 2019), 27 vigorous breath, and loud speech (Asadi et al., 2019)), human heights, and emitted jet 28 waveforms, jet spread angle variability (J. Gupta, Lin, & Chen, 2009), mouth opening 29 variabilities during the emission, and environmental temperature; and 30 (4) Integrate the human respiratory system with the virtual human body shell to simulate the 31 resultant transport and deposition of COVID-19 virus-laden droplets in airways and the 32 triggered immune system responses using established multiscale models (Haghnegahdar 33 et al., 2019; Kuga et al., 2020; Zhao et al., 2019)34

TABREF0.text: ; L. Yang, Li, Yan, & Tu, 2018), this study 15 simulated the transient transport, condensation/evaporation, and deposition of SARS-CoV-2 laden droplets emitted by a cough between two virtual humans with different environmental 17 wind velocities. Initial droplet diameters range from 2 to 2000 microns, and the wind 18 velocities range from 0 to 16 km/h, representing different Beaufort wind scales from calm air to 19 gentle breeze. Ambient relative humidities (RHs) are 40% and 99.5%. The distance between the
